it
Class Graphable

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--it.Graphable
Direct Known Subclasses:
Graph, LineGraph, TrigGraph
public abstract class Graphable
extends java.lang.Object

This is a superclass for all graphable objects. It specifies some of the form and operation for this family of objects. In most cases this can be extended with a user's own evaluateXY method.

Method Detail

removeGraph

public void removeGraph()

setDrawingStyle

public void setDrawingStyle(byte ds)
Sets the style of how the graph is drawn. Graph can either be a CONTINUOUS graph (ie points joined) or a PLOTPOINTS graph (ie just points are plotted).
Parameters:
ds - the drawing style. If it is neither of the two provided constants then it defaults to CONTINUOUS.

setAxes

public final void setAxes(double xMin,
                          double xMax,
                          double yMin,
                          double yMax)
Sets the axes of the graph to be selected values
Parameters:
xMin - The minimum value on the X axis
xMax - The maximum value on the X axis
yMin - The minimum value on the Y axis
yMax - The maximum value on the Y axis

getAxisValues

public final double[] getAxisValues()
Returns the axis values as an array of doubles: xMin, xMax, yMin, yMax respectively.

Sets the axis labels to the given Strings.
Parameters:
xLabel - label for the x axis
yLabel - label for the y axis

b - boolean value for whether to draw title or not

drawGraph

public void drawGraph(java.awt.Graphics g,
                      GraphPanel owner)
This method handles the drawing of the graph to the GraphPanel canvas. It requires that the helper method evaluateXY(Point2D.Double) is defined. The method works in screen coordinate space and graph space. It takes the dimensioning paramaters from the parent and increments pixel-by-pixel along the x-axis. This screen space coordinate is converted to graph-space whereby the helper method evaluateXY(...) has to calculate the corresponding graph-space y-value. This is inturn then converted back to screen-space and a line suitably drawn. In most cases this method can be left alone. If a custom subclass is used it is advised that the work is done in the evaluateXY(...) method and this be left alone. In certain cases it may be required to override this method, though. For an example see PointGraph.
Parameters:
g - the graphics context to draw to.
owner - the controller of graphable components.
